awd_titl_txt: Topology and Contact and Symplectic Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
Symplectic manifolds are spaces equipped with an additional structure coming from classical mechanics. Contact manifolds are in some sense a dimensional simplification, and have historically had connections to the differential equations of optics and dynamics. In recent years, mathematicians have found strong applications of the study of contact and symplectic manifolds to our understanding of three- and four-dimensional spaces. One foundational goal in topology is to understand the extent certain algebraic simplifications of a manifold determine the manifold itself. For example, the famous Poincare Conjecture asks whether the structure of a sphere is determined by a related algebraic entity known as its fundamental group; a four dimensional version of this question is still unanswered. Somewhat surprisingly, symplectic manifolds have played a strong role in answering such questions. In turn, as the field has progressed, mathematicians have used tools from topology, differential geometry and physics with the goal of better understanding contact and symplectic manifolds. This project aims to both use the tools from the study of contact and symplectic manifolds to further our understanding of three- and four-dimensional spaces, as well as to develop new tools to increase our understanding of contact and symplectic manifolds themselves. 

In one sense, contact and symplectic topology bridges the rigidity of Riemannian geometry and the flexibility of topology, showing traits of both: local flexibility and global rigidity. Modern contact topology began in the 1980s with Bennequin's work and was connected to symplectic topology by Gromov and Eliashberg. Giroux brought topology and contact geometry in 3-dimensions closely together by associating a topological object, a singular fiber bundle called an open book decomposition, to a contact structure, as well as a method for describing all open books compatible with that contact structure. This tool has been extremely effective at forming connections with low-dimensional topology, allowing for the construction of new contact invariants, surgery characterization of certain knots, and the classification of symplectic fillings, among much else. Open books additionally provide two new intrinsic invariants of the contact structure: the page, a fiber in the open book, and the monodromy, the gluing map of the bundle. We call the minimal genus of a compatible open book the page genus of the contact structure, and it is an extraordinarily interesting invariant. If the page genus is zero, then we can say a tremendous amount about the contact structure. If the page genus is not zero, then there are infinitely many compatible open books and the existing methods for describing them all are far from effective, which makes determining the page genus impossible. Indeed, it is unknown whether there are contact structures with minimal page genus greater than one. This project aims to simplify this picture, first by producing new invariants of contact manifolds that can be effectively calculated using a given open book; and second by producing effective mechanisms for listing all open books as well as determining whether two open books yield the same contact structure.

por.por_cntn:
When a biologist asks how a protein folds, or a physicist or engineer asks for an understanding of how the design of a robotic arm affects its ability to move, they are principally asking a mathematical question about configuration spaces and the topology of a manifold.

Manifolds are the building blocks of mathematics and have strong connections to problems in physics, biology and engineering, but one of the principal difficulties in expanding their application is that they are generally complicated. While a practical classification for surfaces, 2-dimensional manifolds, has been known for over a century, it is only in the past 20 years that 3-dimensional spaces are becoming even potentially tractable, and our understanding of 4-dimensional spaces remains at the bleeding edge of mathematical research.

These projects aim to increase our understanding of 3-dimensional manifolds equipped with a certain geometric structure with roots in dynamics and optics: a contact structure. We have expanded known tools used to understand contact 3-manifolds and their connections to their 4-dimensional siblings, symplectic 4-manifolds. These tools have roots that reach back to foundational ideas of Gromov and Floer from the 80s, to the ideas of pseudoholomorphic curves and Floer's connection between Yang-Mills gauge theory and the world of symplectic manifolds. We improve on known tools and their ability to differentiate between different contact structures, as well as to detect some of their fundamental properties, and these use a specific structure associated to the contact manifold called an open book decomposition. This structure was constructed in the 30s by Alexander but its application to the study of contact structures on 3-manifolds only began in 2000 by work of Giroux. In one project, we generalize applications of Gromov?s theory of pseudoholomorphic tools. This allows us to complete a long-standing question about which contact structures on an important family of 3-manifolds can arise as the 3-dimensional boundary of a symplectic 4-manifold. In another, we generalize an invariant constructed by Oszvath and Szabo in their Heegaard Floer Homology theory and in doing so expand its ability to detect the important properties of tightness/overtwistedness and Stein-fillability.

While these results are at the cutting edge of research, it is important to both train future researchers capable of continuing such cutting edge research in mathematics, but also in training future leaders in industry who are capable of both understanding this research and also applying it to the problems and questions they are attacking. Doctoral training in pure mathematics is excellent preparation for futures both in and out of academia. Working through a doctoral research project in pure mathematics is fundamentally about receiving and learning foundational training in how to attack an unfamiliar problem using unfamiliar tools, exactly the kind of training leaders in industry need.

Doctoral students who graduate and transition to industry are also one of the best ways we can disseminate the mathematical ideas for core graduate courses to broader industry. One focus we have in advising graduate students is developing computational fluency. During this grant, we have assisted four graduate students in industrial internships and direct collaboration with industry, and these graduate students have learned about cluster and parallel computing tools and general mathematical modeling.

In addition, to help energize the future of research, we ran weekly MOEMS groups for children in grades 4-8 (though younger kids often participated). While focusing on a series of 5 exams, the goal of this group is to foster novel mathematical thinking and promote social interaction. The group is open to anyone and we actively recruit through the local library. We also ran a monthly Saturday Morning Math group. This group exposes younger students to some of the stranger and more interesting ideas in mathematics. We see this as expanding the pipeline of future mathematicians and exposing future physical scientists and engineers to the mathematics that will drive future technological advances.
